body:
### Problem

I want to set some filetypes to be backup-ed. And other filetypes to keep their original. But backupskip applies universaly to backup and patchmode. The same for backupdir. (it would be nice to have a folder with my backup files while patchmoded .orig stay in the original folder.)

Example:

I have two files: an `example1.conf  `and an `example2.text`

Setting backup will create an `example.conf.bak` and an `example.text.bak` (or `example1.conf~` and `example2.text~` as per the original behavior.)

Setting `patchmode` will create `example1.conf.orig` and `example2.text.orig` respectively.

Given my aim is to have `example1.conf.orig` and `example2.text.bak`,

I read the `:h` on `backupskip`.

But (if I understand :h correctly,) `backupskip` applies both to `vim.opt.backup` and `vim.opt.patchmode`.

Therefore, if I was to add the extension `*.conf` to `backupskip`, I would end up with no example1 backup or original, and example2.text.bak along with an exampl2.orig

### Expected behavior

Having a `patchmodeskip` and `patchmodedir` would make for a clean solution to this.

I believe a solution could be devised with autocommands, but I am (rightfully?) reluctant to apply hacky solutions to the save-your-ass functionality that is a backup. It is supposed to to work when everything else fails, after all. In my mind (maybe I am wrong,) autocommandds would compromise it.

comment_data.body:
Is this only about the filenames? I don't see why we need to enhance core functionality to support that. 

Nvim plans to expose a file watcher interface, then you could create a handler that copies or renames the files. 

> I believe a solution could be devised with autocommands, but I am (rightfully?) reluctant to apply hacky solutions to the save-your-ass functionality that is a backup.

If an existing Nvim event is triggered when these backup files are created, then yes, an autocmd handler can safely rename or copy a file (`writefile()` has an fsync flag "s"), then delete the old unwanted file.

Vim/Nvim also has swapfiles and 'undofile' which protect from data loss. But in general your editor is not the best way to protect against data loss, your filesystem or an OS job should do that.

title: Option to backup some filetypes and patchmode others
